Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Supporting Fast-Response Medical Teams Through Interactive Information Displays

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
Modern society increasingly depends on the work of interdisciplinary teams using information and communication technology (ICT) to control complex systems with high reliability (for example, in airplane cockpits, traffic control rooms, and nuclear power plants). Engineered systems such as these are deterministic, with well-defined states and parameters of normal operation which allow control teams to achieve their goals through direct interaction with ICT. But when the focus is a natural (i.e., social or living) system rather than a machine, the control task imposes quite different cognitive demands which make the design, development, and integration of ICT more challenging. High-risk, fast-response medicine is an example of a work environment that deals with a natural system (the patient), where the need for effective ICT support is as high as for engineered systems. The goal of this research is to develop innovative approaches for real-time information presentation to support situation awareness and collaborative work by fast-response, interdisciplinary medical teams. In particular, the PI will examine how context-specific information should be presented to support such teamwork while accounting for team members' perceptual and cognitive limitations. To this end, she will focus on the team-dependent and information-intensive processes of evaluating critically ill patients in the high-risk medical domains of pediatric trauma and emergency resuscitation. The research will involve field studies, video review of medical events, design and development of display prototypes, and evaluation. Project outcomes will include conceptual and empirical understanding of awareness in fast-response medical teamwork, approaches for augmenting distributed cognition through interactive displays, lessons from the development of display prototypes for improving awareness of rapidly unfolding events and their progression, and lessons from evaluating such prototypes in real-world settings.

Broader Impacts: The research will contribute to and inform diverse scientific fields, including information presentation in dynamic environments that rely on interactive information presentation, human-computer interaction where work conditions limit direct interaction with information systems, and the automatic capture and integration of data arriving from multiple sources. Because this research crosses many disciplinary boundaries, it will serve as a platform for an integrated and interdisciplinary education and outreach program.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Critically injured patients have a four-fold higher risk of death from medical errors than other hospitalized patients, with nearly half of preventable deaths related to errors during the initial resuscitation phase. Efficient team response during resuscitation is therefore critical. Although low-tech artifacts and leadership training improve team performance in this setting, protocol deviations and medical errors persist, even with experienced teams. Given the disability and death that can result from team performance gaps, there has been a critical need for effective information and communication technology (ICT) approaches to support the work of fast-response medical teams.

To address this need, in 2012, PI Aleksandra Sarcevic proposed a research program to ?? develop innovative approaches for real-time presentation of process information to support situation awareness and collaborative work of fast-response, interdisciplinary medical teams.?

In the time since the National Science Foundation awarded this grant, the ?Interactive Systems for Healthcare (IS4H)? program led by PI Sarcevic at Drexel University has established an interdisciplinary area of socio-technical research and education that addresses real-world problems by advancing our understanding of high-risk cooperative work and developing approaches to support it through interactive ICT. The IS4H team, assembled under the auspices of the grant, has (1) studied information behaviors of resuscitation teams to inform the design of displays that externalize process information; (2) designed and developed an interactive, digital checklist system to support teamwork; and, (3) implemented the digital checklist during actual patient care and evaluated its impact on team performance. The grant has resulted in 39 publications (4 journal papers, 12 full conference papers, 2 book chapters, 7 short conference papers, 2 workshop papers, and 12 poster presentations). In addition, the grant has trained 4 PhD students, 1 Masters student and 12 Undergraduates in both qualitative and quantitative approaches, including ethnographic fieldwork, video review, and user interface design (e.g., design conceptualizations, prototyping, and evaluation). The goal to improve patient outcomes is being measured by the real-world implementation of the digital checklist system; as of April 2019, the digital checklist was used in 433 actual trauma resuscitations at Children?s National Medical Center in Washington, DC. The goal of training medical staff in design thinking and lowering the ICT adoption barriers is measured by the PI?s frequent presentations at medical conferences, and by the team?s participation in meetings at regional emergency departments.

The research supported by this grant took place at three regional trauma centers?National Children?s Medical Center in Washington DC, and The Children?s Hospital of Philadelphia and The Hospital of the University of Pennsylvania, both in Philadelphia PA?helping establish research relationships between Drexel University and these institutions. Through a series of users studies, the research (a) elicited resuscitation teams? information and awareness needs using participatory design workshops, and (b) described interaction behaviors of team members, as affected by the use of artifacts, using in situ observations, video review of actual resuscitations and interviews. Results from these studies have helped inform the design of an interactive digital checklist system?that is, how best to translate the functions from paper artifacts for seamless and unobtrusive digital interactions.

In a separate set of fieldwork studies, the research identified the order in which critical types of information were documented in both paper and electronic patient records, finding that only 8% of the verbally reported physical exams were documented in near real-time (one minute within the verbal report), while 42% of reports were not documented in the patient records; 38% of information types were documented before the verbal report and 12% were documented with a delay. These results have highlighted the importance of the patient record and how it must be in synch with the workflow, especially when relying on the recorded information for automatic data capture and display in real time.

The process of designing the digital checklist system considered all of the above studies, as the research proceeded with converting the paper checklist to its digital counterpart, initial digital checklist trials to assess its usability, and the real-world implementation in patient care (see Attachment for the final design currently in use at Children?s National). In the final year, the research examined the effects of this checklist system on teamwork by comparing performance on 18 most critical resuscitations tasks from 47 resuscitations that used a paper checklist to that of 47 cases with a digital checklist. The studies showed that using the digital checklist led to more frequent completions of the initial airway assessment task but fewer completions of ear and lower extremities exams. No significant differences were observed in time to task performance. Although improvements in team performance with the digital checklist are minor, these findings are encouraging because they showed no adverse effects as a result of the digital checklist introduction in a highly-complex teamwork setting.
